Weidmann’s early-morning execution was standard by the mid-twentieth century. In the mid-nineteenth century, hoping to dampen the melee that traditionally accompanied public executions, France had moved public executions to the early morning hours. Guillotining continued behind the walls of the country’s prisons until 1977. Capital punishment was finally outlawed under François Mitterrand in 1981.
